Five tickets grouped by shared root cause: mass upload functionality gaps preventing efficient variable pay data entry. Issues range from empty row handling to missing Excel upload UI and lack of pre-population features.

Five tickets grouped by payslip and reporting constraints. Users cannot customize payslip layouts, add remarks to variable pay items, bifurcate salary components, or selectively exclude specific variable pay items from reports.

Three tickets grouped by configuration rigidity: no recovery of deleted payroll items, no self-service payroll cycle date changes, and no ability to reverse cycle modifications without backend support.
Four tickets grouped by lack of self-service deletion capabilities. Platform requires manual backend intervention for account deletion, data erasure, payroll reset, and bulk expense deletion.

Four tickets grouped by data consistency problems: salary arrears cannot be deleted, leave request details lost after deletion, employee deletion not synced to payroll table, and Excel metadata processing errors.

Three tickets grouped by UI/UX constraints: disabled payroll cells hide pay item history, inconsistent variable pay labeling, and generic disclaimer messages that don't adapt to conditional leave policies.
Single ticket addressing lack of administrative controls to suppress employee notifications during active payroll processing periods.
Single ticket addressing rigid payroll template structure that cannot accommodate client-specific field combinations for net additions.
Single ticket highlighting inconsistent employee ID inclusion across export modules despite being an available configurable field.

detected_integrations.description: Variable pay, salary, and addition data is stored and managed through employee profiles. Employee names must match exactly between payroll uploads and employee records.
Payroll cycle configuration changes require backend support and cannot be reversed, indicating tight coupling between cycle settings and payroll processing logic.
Variable pay categories, allowance categories, and salary configurations are created and managed through the Settings > Payroll section.
Bulk operations for variable pay, additions, and salary data use Excel templates for upload and download, with strict formatting requirements.
All variable pay items, additions, and salary adjustments feed into the monthly payroll calculation and processing.
Salary proration configuration interacts with the Daily Wage Calculator to determine calculation basis (custom days, calendar days, or working days)
Salary addition and deduction categories are applied to employees through the Adjustments tab in the Active Payroll Month section
Employee addition requests are tracked through the insurance policy management system with status updates and document delivery
Notifications are sent for missing documents and status updates related to employee addition requests
Leave request deletion does not cascade to payroll deductions, causing orphaned leave deduction records. Leave request details are lost from payroll after leave is processed and deleted.
Work expenses module lacks bulk deletion capability, requiring backend intervention for data cleanup across all expense statuses.
Variable pay approval workflows require integration with the platform's approval engine to enforce managerial review before commission and bonus processing.
Payroll template configuration directly impacts field selection and aggregation capabilities for net additions and deductions.
Mass payroll uploads interact with deduction processing logic; current row-per-deduction structure limits bulk data efficiency.
Payroll export functionality must consistently include employee ID across all report types for data integrity and external system integration.

what_to_do.task: Upload variable pay for multiple employees in bulk
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Start (or Payroll > More options > Mass Upload Variable Pays)
Choose upload method: direct platform entry or Excel template download
If using Excel: Download the Variable Pay template, fill in employee names (must match exactly), variable pay type, dates, amounts, and remarks, then save the file
If using direct platform: Click 'Add new', select employee, enter variable pay details (item type, dates, amounts)
Upload the completed Excel file or confirm direct platform entries
Verify data has been saved to the payroll table
Note: Multiple entries for the same employee are allowed; duplicate uploads will not override previous entries
what_to_do.expected_outcome: Variable pay data for multiple employees is successfully uploaded and reflected in the payroll table. Each employee's monthly salary is updated with the corresponding variable pay items.
rules_and_constraints: Employee names must match exactly as entered on the platform
Do not add or remove columns from the downloaded Excel template
Only cells in black font can be edited; grey-font fields are non-editable from this view
Multiple entries for the same employee with different pay types are allowed
Uploading the same data twice will result in duplicate entries, not overrides
Users can add additional pay categories as needed
edge_cases: Excel upload will fail if employee names do not exactly match platform records
System may display warnings when saving data; review and correct any problematic entries before proceeding
Clicking 'Restart' will lose all entered data
Non-editable fields can be modified through the employee profile for certain data types

what_to_do.task: Add variable pay to an individual employee's current month salary
steps: Navigate to the specific employee's profile
Click on the Payroll tab
Click on the Active Payroll Month tab
Click 'Add/Edit Variable Pay Item'
Select the variable pay type (e.g., commission, bonus, overtime)
Specify the date range for the variable pay
Enter the amount
Optionally add remarks (visible when hovering over the item, showing creator and timestamp)
Save the variable pay item
what_to_do.expected_outcome: The variable pay item is successfully added to the employee's current month salary. The item appears in the payroll tab and is reflected in the employee's monthly salary calculation.
rules_and_constraints: Variable pay must be associated with a specific date range
Variable pay items can include optional remarks for documentation
Only editable fields (black font) can be modified from this view
edge_cases: Remarks are visible to other users when hovering over the item, displaying the creator name and timestamp
Multiple variable pay items can be added for the same employee in the same month

what_to_do.task: Configure Salary Proration and Daily Wage Calculation
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily Wage Calculation
Review the current calculation basis setting
Select the desired calculation basis from available options: custom days, calendar days, or working days
Save the changes
If payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions exist, reject existing prorated salary transactions
Resave the prorated salary transactions to apply the new calculation basis
Confirm that the new proration settings are applied to all active (unpaid) payroll amounts
what_to_do.expected_outcome: Salary proration settings are updated and applied to all active payroll transactions. Employee salaries are calculated proportionally based on actual days worked using the selected calculation basis.
rules_and_constraints: Changes to proration settings affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table
When payroll month is open, super admin must reject existing prorated salary transactions before saving new proration settings
Three calculation bases are available: custom days, calendar days, or working days
Proration affects both first salary calculations and end-of-service settlements
edge_cases: When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions exist, super admin must manually reject and resave transactions to apply new settings
Changes to calculation basis retroactively affect all active unpaid transactions

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The variable pay bulk upload system has multiple gaps that prevent efficient data entry: empty rows are not automatically removed during import, Excel file uploads fail with certain formats, there is no direct upload UI within the payroll table interface, and the system cannot pre-populate variable pay items for bulk operations. Users must manually clean data, enter items individually, or work around format restrictions.

The payroll reporting system lacks flexibility in multiple areas: payslips use a fixed, non-customizable template that cannot display variable pay remarks or bifurcate fixed/variable salary components, variable pay remarks are not visible in exported reports (only in individual employee profiles), and custom payroll reports cannot selectively exclude specific variable pay items (only all-or-nothing exclusion). Users cannot tailor payslips to their organizational needs or provide detailed context for variable compensation.

The payroll configuration system lacks flexibility and recovery mechanisms: deleted payroll configuration items (variable pay items, additions, deductions) cannot be recovered or restored, payroll cycle dates cannot be changed via self-service UI (requires backend support), and cycle date changes cannot be reversed without manual intervention. Users are locked into initial configurations with no ability to correct mistakes or adapt to changing business needs.

The platform lacks self-service UI capabilities for data deletion and account management: users cannot delete account data or perform complete data erasure without support team intervention, there is no self-service payroll module reset feature (requires backend support), and bulk deletion of work expenses across all statuses is not available via UI. All deletion operations require manual backend engineering support, increasing operational overhead and response times.

The platform has data consistency issues across payroll and related modules: salary arrears cannot be deleted even for inactive employees (while adjustments can be deleted), leave request details are lost from payroll deductions after the original leave request is processed and deleted, deleted employees remain in the payroll table and must be manually removed, and Excel metadata processing for variable pay has technical constraints causing data transformation errors. These issues create orphaned data and tracking gaps.

The platform has UI/UX constraints that interrupt workflows: when payroll table cells are disabled, users cannot access pay item history popups, creating a workflow gap for historical data retrieval; variable pay item section labels are inconsistent on the salary configuration page, potentially causing user confusion; and disclaimer messages for conditional leave policies are generic and do not adapt to nuanced pay structures, leading to potential misunderstandings about policy implications.

The platform lacks administrative controls to suppress employee visibility and notifications during active payroll processing periods. Payroll managers cannot prevent employees from receiving notifications about compensation changes made during an open payroll month, which may expose sensitive information or create confusion during the processing cycle.

The payroll template system enforces predefined field combinations for net additions that cannot be customized to match client-specific requirements. Users cannot select or aggregate custom fields within templates, forcing workarounds or manual calculations outside the platform.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Missing Approval Workflow for Variable Compensation
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Variable pay components (commissions, bonuses) lack configurable approval workflows. The platform does not enforce managerial review or oversight before variable compensation is processed, creating potential compliance and governance gaps.

Mass payroll uploads require users to create a separate row for each deduction type per employee. This row-per-deduction-per-employee structure significantly increases data entry complexity and processing time, especially for employees with multiple deduction categories.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Inconsistent Employee ID in Export Reporting
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Employee ID is not uniformly included across all payroll export modules, despite being available as an admin-configurable field. This inconsistency creates identification challenges when users export payroll data for reporting or external system integration.
